title: Flappie Lochner
text:
George Philip "Flappie" Lochner (11 January 1914 – 30 January 1996) was a South African <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player.
Biography.
Lochner was born in <a href="Vanrhynsdorp">Vanrhynsdorp</a>. He attended the Hoërskool Dirkie Uys in <a href="Moorreesburg">Moorreesburg</a>, after which he studied at <a href="Stellenbosch%20University">Stellenbosch University</a>. After completing his studies, Lochner began teaching, first in Cradock and later at <a href="Kingswood%20College%20%28South%20Africa%29">Kingswood College</a> in <a href="Grahamstown">Grahamstown</a>. In 1935 he made his provincial debut for the.
Lochner was a member of the <a href="1937%20South%20Africa%20rugby%20union%20tour%20of%20Australia%20and%20New%20Zealand">1937 Springbok touring team to Australia and New Zealand</a> and played his first <a href="Test%20match%20%28rugby%20union%29">test match</a> for on 25 September 1937 against the <a href="All%20Blacks">All Blacks</a> at <a href="Eden%20Park">Eden Park</a> in Auckland. Lochner also played 9 tour matches and scored eight tries. In 1938 he played in two test matches against the <a href="1938%20British%20Lions%20tour%20to%20South%20Africa">touring team from the British Isles</a>, scoring one try.
Lochner returned to Stellenbosch in 1939 to further his studies where he played for. In 1940 he became a lecturer at the Wellington Training College and played for Wellington Club and for from 1940 to 1943. He later served as selector and manager of the Springbok team.
